data.title: Metric and imperial directions
data.solution:
import sys
startx, starty, ndir = [int(i) for i in input().split()]

startunit = input()

translation = {'ft':0.3048,'yd':0.9144,'m':1,'km':1000,'mi':1609,'lea':4828}

startx*=translation[startunit]
starty*=translation[startunit]

for i in range(ndir):
    xdir,ydir,unit = input().split(' ')
    xdir = float(xdir)
    ydir = float(ydir)
    startx+=xdir*translation[unit]
    starty+=ydir*translation[unit]

startx/=translation[startunit]
starty/=translation[startunit]

print(int(startx+0.5),int(starty+0.5))
data.statement:
An international team is exploring a new area. One by one they keep track of the route - some team members with Imperial System units (foot, yard, mile, league), others with the Metric System (meter, kilometer). Based on their starting coordinates [[startx]] and [[starty]] in a certain unit [[startunit]], and adding all subsequent displacements in the x- and y- direction [[distx]],[[disty]] (in a variety of units), your goal is to calculate their final x- and y-position <<in the same unit as the [[startunit]]>>, rounded to the nearest whole number.

Use the following formulas to convert units:
1 foot <<ft>> = 0.3048 meters
1 yard <<yd>> = 0.9144 meters
1 kilometer <<km>> = 1000 meters (how incredibly convenient!)
1 mile <<mi>> = 1609 meters
1 league <<lea>> = 4828 meters

lastVersion.statementHTML:
Goal

An international team is exploring a new area. One by one they keep track of the route - some team members with Imperial System units (foot, yard, mile, league), others with the Metric System (meter, kilometer). Based on their starting coordinates startx and starty in a certain unit startunit, and adding all subsequent displacements in the x- and y- direction distx,disty (in a variety of units), your goal is to calculate their final x- and y-position in the same unit as the startunit, rounded to the nearest whole number.

Use the following formulas to convert units:
1 foot ft = 0.3048 meters
1 yard yd = 0.9144 meters
1 kilometer km = 1000 meters (how incredibly convenient!)
1 mile mi = 1609 meters
1 league lea = 4828 meters
Input
Line 1 : 3 space-separated integers: starting position startx, starty and number of directions ndir.
Line 2: a string: the unit of the starting position startunit (one of ft, yd, m, km, mi or lea).
Next ndir lines: a string direction, with three space separated values: displacement in x- and y-direction (these can be floats), and the corresponding unit (one of ft, yd, m, km, mi or lea).
Output
Final x- and y-position rounded to whole numbers, in the startunit relative to x=0,y=0.
Constraints
startx,starty, and final x- and y-coordinates >= 0.
Example
Input
0 0 3
m
10 10 m
1 1 km
100 100 yd
Output
1101 1101
